__data__.text: The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) established chapters in Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska in 1982 after merging with the Brothers MC. The Alaskan Hells Angels have been involved in methamphetamine trafficking. In 1985, an Alaskan Hells Angels member became an FBI informant and provided information on the club's criminal activities for two years, leading to the arrest of 38 members in 1987 on drug, weapon, explosive, and conspiracy charges. In 2003, four Alaskan Hells Angels were arrested on federal racketeering and firearms charges following a conflict in Nevada that left three bikers dead. The club has been linked to violent incidents in Alaska, including a stabbing in 2017 involving a Hells Angels member and a white supremacist prison gang. In 2019, five members of the prison gang were arrested and charged with murder, kidnapping, and racketeering crimes, including drug trafficking, involving a Hells Angels member.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in criminal activities such as methamphetamine trafficking, violence, and racketeering in Alaska. In 1985, an Alaskan Hells Angels member became an FBI informant, leading to the arrest of 38 members in 1987. In 2003, four members were arrested on federal racketeering and firearms charges. The club has been linked to violent incidents, including a stabbing in 2017 and a murder in 2019 involving a Hells Angels member and a white supremacist prison gang. In Arizona, the HAMC is classified as a criminal street gang and is involved in methamphetamine production and distribution. The club has approximately a hundred members in Arizona and established six chapters in the state after merging with the Dirty Dozen in 1997. In 2001, two members were arrested for narcotics trafficking after the DEA uncovered an international drug network involving the smuggling of methamphetamine from South Africa. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) initiated an undercover investigation into the Arizona Hells Angels in 2001, resulting in the arrest of several members on drug and firearm charges.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) in Arizona was the target of a lengthy undercover investigation called Operation Black Biscuit, initiated by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) in 2001. An ATF agent named Kramer infiltrated the club by posing as a methamphetamine and firearms dealer, eventually gaining the trust of Hells Angels leaders. The ATF used this connection to form a relationship between the Hells Angels and a fabricated Solo Angeles biker group. In 2003, undercover agent Jay Dobyns staged a murder of a Mongols member to bolster the Solo Angeles' credibility, which led to Dobyns' alleged acceptance into the Hells Angels' Skull Valley chapter. However, the HAMC has denied his membership. The operation was cut short due to concerns about a Hells Angels member, Robert "Chico" Mora, planning to kill the Solo Angeles, believing they were a rival gang encroaching on their territory. The investigation resulted in the arrest of 52 people and the seizure of illegal weapons, but internal disagreements led to half of the defendants plea bargaining to lesser offenses, and five others had federal charges dismissed. The Skull Valley chapter disbanded following the investigation.

In a separate incident, Hells Angels members Kevin J. Augustiniak, Michael Christopher "Mesa Mike" Kramer, and prospective member Paul Merle Eischeid murdered Cynthia Yvonne Garcia in 2001, due to her verbal disrespect towards the club while intoxicated during a party. The three bikers beat Garcia unconscious, drove her to the desert, and stabbed her 27 times, attempting to decapitate her. Her body was discovered on October 31, 2001.

The conviction of the Hells Angels (HAMC) members involved in Cynthia Garcia's murder was overturned in 2002. Garcia, a 44-year-old mother of six, was killed by HAMC members Kevin J. Augustiniak, Michael Christopher "Mesa Mike" Kramer, and Paul Merle Eischeid due to her disrespect towards the club. Her body was found in the desert near the Salt River, showing signs of brutal stabbing and attempted decapitation. Kramer became an informant for the ATF and offered information on the murder in exchange for immunity, while Eischeid fled the country and was apprehended in Argentina in 2011. Augustiniak was sentenced to 23 years and six months in prison in 2012. The Skull Valley chapter disbanded due to the investigation, and internal conflicts led to plea bargains and dismissed charges for several defendants. The murder of HAMC member Joshua William Harber and chapter president Daniel Leroy "Hoover" Seybert remain unsolved cold cases, with various theories surrounding their deaths. In 2015, HAMC treasurer Patrick Michael Eberhardt was shot dead in Phoenix.

In 2007, two Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) members from Arizona, Rodney Cox and Calvin Schaefer, were convicted for a violent crime related to racketeering after being extradited to Las Vegas. Schaefer received a sentence of four years and three months, while Cox was sentenced to two years. In 2015, HAMC treasurer Patrick Michael Eberhardt was shot dead in Phoenix, and a Mongols member is a suspect in his murder. HAMC member Wayne Whitt shot and killed a Mongols member in Tempe in 2016, but no charges were filed against him. Conflicts between the Hells Angels, Desert Road Riders, and Vagos resulted in several arrests in Mohave County in 2009 and 2012. HAMC member Nathaniel Barton Sample was convicted of aggravated assault and acting for the benefit of a street gang in 2009. Former Tucson Hells Angels chapter president William Gary "Tramp" Potter was sentenced to nineteen years in prison in 2012 for second-degree murder and weapons charges. HAMC Yavapai County chapter treasurer Bruce Schweigert, Sr. was sentenced to eight years in prison in 2014 for threatening and intimidating as a gang member, assault, disorderly conduct, and weapons misconduct.

In 2012, Hells Angels (HAMC) member Potter was sentenced to nineteen years for second-degree murder and weapons charges, and Yavapai County chapter treasurer Bruce Schweigert, Sr. received an eight-year sentence for threatening and intimidating as a gang member, assault, disorderly conduct, and weapons misconduct. The HAMC, a significant motorcycle gang in California and Colorado, is involved in methamphetamine manufacture and distribution, and has infiltrated legitimate businesses. Violent incidents involving the HAMC have occurred in Colorado, such as shootings and bar fights. In 2017, prospective member John Lockhart was charged with attempted first-degree murder, vehicular eluding, and illegal discharge of a firearm after shooting at two vehicles, including a police car. He was convicted of vehicular eluding and acquitted of attempted first-degree murder and illegal discharge of a firearm in 2019.

In 2012, Hells Angels (HAMC) members Potter and Bruce Schweigert, Sr. were sentenced for violent crimes and weapons charges. The HAMC, known for methamphetamine manufacture and distribution, has a history of violent incidents in Colorado. In 2017, prospective member John Lockhart was involved in a road rage incident, shooting at a SUV and a police car, and was sentenced to 32 years in 2019. In 2020, HAMC members were involved in a gun battle in Arvada, leaving one member dead and three injured. The Denver chapter clubhouse was raided in 2001 due to illegal activities, resulting in a lawsuit and a $50,000 settlement. HAMC members have been arrested for possession of handguns and unconstitutional traffic stops, leading to lawsuits and settlements. In 2018, a HAMC member sued LaSalle police officer David Miller for threatening to shoot him, resulting in a $25,000 settlement and an apology. In 2019, HAMC member Dustin "Dusty" Ullerich was injured during a no-knock warrant execution and filed a lawsuit against multiple police departments.

In September 2020, Hells Angels (HAMC) member Dustin "Dusty" Ullerich received a $25,000 settlement and an apology from police officer David Miller as part of a lawsuit over injuries suffered during a no-knock warrant execution in 2019. In November 2019, 13 HAMC members and one member of the Destroyers motorcycle gang were indicted on charges related to an organized crime ring in Denver. The investigation began in July 2019 after former HAMC member Joshua O'Bryan provided information on the club's alleged involvement in various criminal activities. In 1975, the Bridgeport chapter of the HAMC was involved in a series of violent incidents, including a police officer being attacked with a baseball bat and the death of José Sosa, which led to the arrest of several members. The Bridgeport chapter was also linked to the Mafia as enforcers and contract killers.

In 1975, a violent confrontation between the Bridgeport Hells Angels (HAMC) and Donald Krosky, associated with the rival Huns Motorcycle Club, resulted in the deaths of two HAMC members and critical injury to another. Krosky was charged with murder but was later killed in 1976, with police suspecting Donald Meredith, another HAMC member, as the gunman. In 1977, HAMC member Frank Passalaqua was investigated for the homicide of a black inmate at Northern Correctional Institution. Daniel Bifield, the HAMC Bridgeport chapter president, was arrested in 1979 for possessing a shotgun and was sentenced to prison. Joseph Whelan, a HAMC member, fatally stabbed a bar patron in 1980 and received a lengthy prison sentence. In 1998, Daniel Klimas, a Hells Angels sergeant-at-arms, murdered a rejected club prospect and was sentenced to 28 years in prison. Roger Mariani, a senior Hells Angels member, was shot and killed in 2006, with two Hells Angels members arrested near an Outlaws member's home in possession of weapons and stolen police documents. The Hells Angels are suspected of involvement in the 2010 murder of the Outlaws' Waterbury chapter president and the 2016 assault of a debtor by Hells Angels associate Howard Hammer, acting on behalf of a loanshark.

In 1975-2016, the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) and its members were involved in various criminal activities, including murder, possession of weapons, assault, extortion, loansharking, drug trafficking, and racketeering. Some key events include:

1. A violent confrontation in 1975 between HAMC and the Huns Motorcycle Club, resulting in deaths and injuries.
2. HAMC member Frank Passalaqua's investigation for a 1977 homicide.
3. Daniel Bifield's arrest in 1979 for possessing a shotgun and his subsequent imprisonment.
4. Joseph Whelan's stabbing of a bar patron in 1980 and his lengthy prison sentence.
5. Daniel Klimas's murder of a rejected club prospect in 1998 and his 28-year prison sentence.
6. Roger Mariani's shooting in 2006, with two HAMC members arrested near an Outlaws member's home in possession of weapons and stolen police documents.
7. The Hells Angels' suspected involvement in the 2010 murder of the Outlaws' Waterbury chapter president and the 2016 assault of a debtor by Hells Angels associate Howard Hammer.

In late December 2015, Hells Angels associate Howard Hammer, acting on behalf of loanshark James Broderick III, attacked a delinquent debtor who falsely claimed to be the acting president of the New York Hells Angels chapter. The debtor was stabbed eight times, beaten with a hammer, and blinded in one eye. Hammer and Broderick were arrested in May 2016, but no one has been arrested in connection with the assault. Hammer pleaded guilty to conspiracy and was sentenced to two-and-a-half years' imprisonment. Broderick also pleaded guilty and received a two-year sentence.

In 1981, Daniel Bifield and two associates, including his father Richard Bifield, were convicted of conspiring to make and collect extortionate loans and Hobbs Act violations for their involvement in a loansharking operation. Daniel Bifield escaped

From 1975 to 2016, the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) and its members were involved in various criminal activities, including murder, weapons possession, assault, extortion, loansharking, drug trafficking, and racketeering. Numerous key events and convictions occurred during this time period, such as the arrests and imprisonments of HAMC members for violent crimes and loansharking. The HAMC was also involved in conflicts with rival motorcycle clubs, such as the Huns Motorcycle Club and the Outlaws. In some instances, these conflicts resulted in deaths, injuries, and arrests. Additionally, HAMC members have been convicted of conspiring to make and collect extortionate loans and Hobbs Act violations. The club has also been involved in various drug trafficking operations and has been suspected of involvement in several murders. In 2016, Hells Angels associate Howard Hammer attacked a debtor on behalf of loanshark James Broderick III, resulting in Hammer's arrest and conviction.

In 1981, 35 members of the HAMC were charged and convicted, including Roger "Bear" Mariani, Robert "Red Dog" Redmann, and Joseph Whelan, who were each sentenced to 15 years in prison. One Hells Angel, Robert Banning, became a cooperating witness. In 1986, detective Nicholas Barone of the Connecticut State Police received intelligence indicating that he and H. James Pickerstein, Chief Assistant U.S. Attorney for the District of Connecticut, were to be physically harmed by the HAMC in retaliation for their efforts in the investigation and subsequent prosecutions. In 2005, four leading members of the Hells Angels in northern Illinois were arrested and charged with numerous crimes including violating the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act, resulting in convictions and prison sentences. In 2016, law enforcement in Indiana received public backlash for heavily patrolling a charity event held by the HAMC. From 1975 to 2004, the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) in Massachusetts was involved in various criminal activities, including drug trafficking, firearm possession, assault, and loansharking. The club has established multiple chapters in the state and has been linked to violent incidents, such as a battle with police in Lowell in 1969 and the abduction and assault of a man in 1975. In 2003, several members of the North Beach chapter were arrested on federal drug and firearm charges. In 2004, two Hells Angels were accused of raping a woman and assaulting a police lieutenant. The HAMC has been the most significant motorcycle gang involved in drug trafficking in Massachusetts and has collaborated with the Boston faction of the Patriarca crime family in loansharking and narcotics distribution. Law enforcement has conducted several investigations and arrests of HAMC members in the state. In some cases, charges were dropped or convictions were overturned due to issues with witness cooperation or judicial errors. The HAMC has been known to retaliate against law enforcement officials who investigate and prosecute them. In 1986, for example, the HAMC planned to physically harm a detective and a Chief Assistant U.S. Attorney in Connecticut in retaliation for their efforts in an investigation and subsequent prosecutions. In 2016, law enforcement in Indiana received public backlash for heavily patrolling a charity event held by the HAMC. In 2016, an Hells Angels associate was arrested and convicted for attacking a debtor on behalf of a loanshark. In 2005, four leading members of the Hells Angels in northern Illinois were arrested and charged with numerous crimes, including violating the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act, resulting in convictions and prison sentences. The HAMC and its members have been involved in various criminal activities and conflicts with rival motorcycle clubs from 1975 to 2016.

From 1974 to 2013, the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) in Massachusetts was involved in various criminal activities and conflicts with rival motorcycle clubs. In 1974, a conflict with a rival club, Lucifer's Henchmen MC, led to the unsolved murder of a HAMC member and the injury of another. The HAMC reportedly emerged victorious in the feud. In 1997, two HAMC members were accused of raping a woman. In 2004, members were charged with assaulting a police officer and an off-duty police lieutenant. In 2005, a member was arrested for assaulting his girlfriend and possessing a firearm, and another member was arrested for attacking a debtor on behalf of a loanshark. In 2011, a member was found with a firearm and ammunition after assaulting his girlfriend. In 2013, several members were arrested and charged with kidnapping, mayhem, and extortion, among other crimes, resulting in convictions and imprisonment. The HAMC and its members have been involved in various criminal activities and conflicts with rival motorcycle clubs from 1974 to 2013.

(Note: The incident with Leary was not included in the summary as it was not a criminal activity or conflict with a rival club, but an individual legal dispute with law enforcement)

From 1974 to 2016, the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) in Massachusetts was involved in various conflicts with rival motorcycle clubs, including Lucifer's Henchmen MC and the Devil's Disciples MC. These conflicts resulted in violent incidents, such as stabbings, shootings, and assaults. The HAMC was also linked to criminal activities, such as drug trafficking, weapons possession, and attacks on behalf of loansharks. The conflicts and criminal activities led to arrests, convictions, and imprisonment of HAMC members. Additionally, HAMC members were suspects in unsolved murders, including the murder of a drug dealer in 1984 and a missing woman in 1979, whose car was found abandoned and burned. The woman's roommate and HAMC prospect was also found murdered, and HAMC member Michele Gagnon was a prime suspect in both cases. Gagnon was later found dead in an apartment in Bridgeport, Connecticut, with his death ruled a suicide, although some authorities believe he did not take his own life.

From 1974 to 2011, the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) in Massachusetts was involved in various conflicts, criminal activities, and murders. These incidents included violent conflicts with rival clubs, drug trafficking, weapons possession, and attacks on behalf of loansharks. Several HAMC members were suspects in unsolved murders, and some were convicted of murder. For example, Vincent DeNino, a drug dealer, was allegedly killed by the HAMC over a drug debt in 1984. In 1985, five HAMC members were arrested for conspiracy to distribute cocaine, and in 1991, thirteen members were indicted for conspiracy to distribute methamphetamine. The club's violent and criminal activities led to arrests, convictions, and imprisonment of members. The HAMC was also linked to the murders of three people in Canada, directly related to a methamphetamine lab case. The club's involvement in criminal activities and violence had significant consequences for its members and the communities they operated in.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) in Massachusetts was involved in various criminal activities, including drug trafficking and violence. During a 1991 operation, authorities seized large quantities of illegal drugs and weapons, leading to the arrests and convictions of several HAMC members. In 1993, thirteen members were sentenced for their involvement in a methamphetamine distribution ring. In 1995, an undercover DEA agent infiltrated the Salem chapter, resulting in the arrests of sixteen members and associates in 1996 for drug trafficking. The club's violent activities, such as attacks on rival gang members, also led to arrests and convictions. In 1986, two HAMC members were arrested for firearms charges, and in 1987, eleven members, including a HAMC member, were indicted for loansharking and racketeering. A joint investigation in 2007 led to the arrests of six club members on various charges.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club in Massachusetts and its chapters in Boston and Salem have been involved in various criminal activities, including drug trafficking, violence, loansharking, and racketeering. In 1987, eleven members, including Mark "Rebel" McKenna, were indicted for operating a large loansharking ring that collected millions of dollars. In 2007, a joint investigation led to the arrests of six club members on various charges. In April 2022, a shooting occurred at the clubhouse in Springfield, Missouri, resulting in one member being shot. The club has also been involved in violent incidents in Nebraska, such as assaults, brawls with police, and bombings. In 1968, Hells Angels member Orval Hinz was charged with first-degree murder, along with two other individuals, after a man was shot and killed in Omaha.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club in Nebraska has been involved in various criminal activities, including murder and drug trafficking. In 1968, three members were charged with first-degree murder after a man was shot and killed in Omaha. In 1975, another member was arrested for murdering a woman at a drug party and dumping her body in Iowa. The club has also been involved in drug trafficking, with members selling heroin and methamphetamine in Omaha in the early 1970s. In 1981, ten members and associates were indicted for their role in a conspiracy to monopolize the methamphetamine trade in the Omaha area using intimidation, assault, torture, and murder. The conspiracy, which began in 1972, is suspected in the unsolved murder of a man in 1979. An investigation in 1981 resulted in the recovery of weapons and narcotics and six arrests. Witt, a member, died in prison in 2019.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club in Nebraska has been involved in criminal activities such as murder and drug trafficking since the 1970s. They obtained drugs, including methamphetamine and heroin, from other chapters and distributed them in Omaha. In 1981, a conspiracy to monopolize the methamphetamine trade in the Omaha area was exposed, resulting in indictments and convictions of several members. Operation Zookeeper, a three-year undercover investigation targeting a cocaine distribution network, led to the arrests and convictions of numerous Hells Angels members in 1985. In 1990, a two-year investigation resulted in the indictment of several members on charges including racketeering, money laundering, and drug trafficking. The River Run Riot in 2002 involved a confrontation between Hells Angels and Mongols members, resulting in deaths and injuries. In 2007, two Hells Angels members were sentenced to prison for their role in the riot.

In 2007, Hells Angels members James Hannigan and Rodney Cox were sentenced to prison for their role in a confrontation with Mongols bikers at a casino, where a Hells Angel was seen on video attacking a Mongol member. Both sides accused each other of initiating the fight, with witnesses reporting incidents of harassment by the Mongols prior to the altercation. In 1969, Hells Angels members in New Hampshire were arrested for narcotics-related charges, resulting in convictions and imprisonment. In the 1970s, the Hells Angels were involved in conflicts with the Breed and the Devil's Disciples, including a grenade attack and a shooting, leading to arrests and convictions. The Hells Angels established a chapter in New Jersey in 2002, following a treaty with the Pagans, and have been involved in drug trafficking and violent incidents in the state. In 2005, three Hells Angels were beaten by a group of Pagans outside a bar in Woodland Township.

The Hells Angels established a chapter in New Jersey in 2002, following a truce with the Pagans. However, conflicts between the two clubs persist, such as a violent incident in 2005 involving a group of Pagans beating three Hells Angels with a wooden board in South Jersey. The Hells Angels' East Coast leader, John "The Baptist" LoFranco, reportedly declared war on the Pagans after this incident. In addition to conflicts with rival clubs, the Hells Angels have been involved in criminal activities such as drug trafficking, weapons possession, and violence. For example, in 2015, four Hells Angels members were indicted for possessing weapons and controlled dangerous substances. The club has also been linked to mafia organizations, specifically the Gambino and Genovese crime families, and has been accused of providing security and transportation in narcotics deals in exchange for drugs and contract killings. Furthermore, the Hells Angels have been associated with rape and sexual assault, as seen in the 1971 gang rape of a 17-year-old girl in New York City. The club has also been involved in assaults and murders, such as the 1975 shooting of a college student in Connecticut in retaliation for a car crash. The Hells Angels have also been criticized for their alleged involvement in the beating of a woman outside their clubhouse in Manhattan in 2007, although they deny any connection. The NYPD's investigation of the incident was criticized by the club, leading to a legal threat of false arrest and possible civil rights violations.

The Hells Angels, despite denying involvement in a beating incident, have been linked to criminal activities such as drug trafficking, weapons possession, and violence. In 2010, a methamphetamine trafficking network run by the Rochester chapter of the Hells Angels was dismantled, with several members receiving prison sentences. The club's North Carolina chapters, established in the 1970s, have been involved in criminal rackets, drug and prostitution rings, and feuds with rival gangs. In 1981, the murder of a prominent Hells Angels member in North Carolina remains unsolved and is believed to be related to a feud with the Outlaws or internal power struggle. The club has also been accused of possessing illegal weapons and assaulting law enforcement officers.

After the Hells Angels' Charlotte chapter became weakened due to internal violence and imprisonments, it was disbanded and its clubhouse was burned down in 1985. The club has been linked to criminal activities such as drug trafficking, weapons possession, and violence. In 1982, Hells Angels members Fred Martin Scarnechia and Thomas Lee Campbell assaulted a federal agent during a drug deal sting operation, and were later sentenced to five years in prison. A subsequent search of a storage unit uncovered a cache of weapons, including explosives and automatic weapons. The club has also been involved in contract killings and feuds with rival gangs, resulting in multiple deaths and injuries. In one such incident in 1971, five bikers were killed and twenty-three people were injured during a brawl between the Hells Angels and the Breed in Cleveland. The Hells Angels have also been linked to a murder in 1988, when a member was mistakenly killed in a case of mistaken identity. In Oregon, the Hells Angels have avoided operating since 1967 due to an agreement with the Gypsy Jokers. A Hells Angels prospect was convicted of a quadruple murder in 1994 in Gaston.

After the Hells Angels (HA) were expelled from Oregon in 1967 due to a drug war with the Gypsy Jokers, they only returned in 1994 when a prospect was convicted of a quadruple murder. The HA have historically been prevented from establishing a presence in the Philadelphia area by an alliance between the Pagans and the Philadelphia crime family. In 2002, there were several violent incidents between the clubs, and the Philadelphia HA chapter was disbanded in 2005 due to poor leadership. The HA's Rhode Island chapter, established in 1992, has a working relationship with the Providence faction of the Patriarca crime family. A HA member from New Rochelle, New York was sentenced to 15 years in prison in 2012 for a federal firearms charge.

The Philadelphia Hells Angels (HA) chapter was disbanded in 2005 due to poor leadership, and the HA's Rhode Island chapter, established in 1992, has a working relationship with the Providence faction of the Patriarca crime family. In 2012, a HA member from New Rochelle, New York was sentenced to 15 years in prison for a federal firearms charge, and in 2019, another HA member in Rhode Island was sentenced to seven years for trafficking drugs and being a felon in possession of a firearm. The HA's first chapter in the Southern States was established in Charleston, South Carolina in 1976, and a HA member from that chapter was killed in a bar brawl in 1982. In 1983, the president of the HA's Charlotte, North Carolina chapter and another club member were sentenced to five years in prison for assaulting a DEA agent. In 2013, sixteen members and associates of the HA's South Carolina Nomads chapter were convicted of crimes related to the RICO Act, including drug dealing, money laundering, and firearms trafficking. The HA's leadership coordinated the criminal activity and received kickbacks from proceeds. The chapter's leadership transitioned from a long-time HA member to a recent inductee during the investigation.

The Hells Angels (HA) leadership in the South Carolina Nomads chapter changed from a seasoned member "Diamond" Dan Bifield to a recent inductee Mark "Lightning" Baker after Bifield was removed as president due to poor leadership. The transition occurred during a law enforcement investigation that began in 2011 when Bifield made a drug deal with an informant. The operation resulted in the arrest of sixteen HA members and associates, who were later sentenced to over 100 years in prison collectively for crimes related to the RICO Act. In 2018, four HA members and one prospect from the New York metropolitan area were convicted of ambushing and wounding two Pagans gang members in Virginia. Meanwhile, in Washington, the HA established a Nomads chapter in 1994, and in 2001, former HA member Rodney Lee Rollness and others were convicted of murdering a man who falsely claimed to be a HA member.
